result.title: Your IQ Result
result.lookup_hint: Paste your ID to open your detailed report.
result.disclaimer_iq: This IQ estimate is calculated using normalized z-scores across five cognitive domains: reasoning, math, verbal, spatial, and memory. The scoring model is based on Gaussian normalization of ICAR-like items, scaled to μ = 100 and σ = 15. Scores are indicative, not diagnostic.
result.iq_explainer_short: Your IQ estimate (mean = 100, SD = 15) is plotted on a normal curve. Most people fall between 85 – 115. Shaded regions mark standard ability bands used in research and education.
result.explainer_long: Scores are derived from your accuracy across cognitive domains. Each correct answer contributes to a weighted z-score, normalized to the reference mean (μ = 100, σ = 15). The 95 % confidence interval (CI) reflects expected statistical variation given the number of items answered.
result.explanation_method: The IQ computation method follows psychometric conventions similar to ICAR (Condon & Revelle, 2014) and WAIS standardization norms (Wechsler, 2008). Z-scores per domain are averaged and scaled to match a standard normal distribution. Percentiles are then derived from the cumulative normal distribution Φ(z). This approach is transparent and reproducible.
result.references: References: Condon, D. M. & Revelle, W. (2014). The International Cognitive Ability Resource: Development and initial validation. Intelligence, 43, 52-64. | Wechsler, D. (2008). WAIS-IV Manual. Pearson Assessment.
result.iq_curve_caption: The curve below shows how your estimated IQ compares to the general population.

report.overview: Your result summarizes performance across five major cognitive domains.
report.interpretation: Scores are standardized to have a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. Values between 85–115 are within the typical range. Higher scores indicate stronger reasoning and cognitive flexibility.
report.categories_explainer: The per-category results help you understand your cognitive strengths and development areas.

about.title: About this test
about.method: This test is inspired by the International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR) and public-domain cognitive items. It provides an open, transparent way to estimate general reasoning ability (g). The dataset and scoring methods are freely available for research use.
about.audience: Suitable for ages 14 and up, for educational, personal, or HR screening use. No identifying data is stored — only an anonymous ID for comparison over time.
about.limitations: This test is not a substitute for professional psychometric assessment. Environmental factors, mood, and language proficiency can affect results.

iq_explainer.title: How your IQ estimate is calculated
iq_explainer.intro: This free assessment uses open-source, research-based methods to approximate general cognitive ability (g). It is designed for educational, self-assessment, and research purposes — not as a clinical or hiring diagnostic. However, it follows psychometric principles comparable to those used in standardized instruments.

method.heading: Calculation method
method.p1: Each question contributes a raw accuracy score (correct or partial credit). These scores are weighted by category reliability and combined across five core domains: Reasoning, Math, Verbal, Spatial, and Memory.
method.p2: The total is converted into a standardized score (Z-score) using the mean (μ) and standard deviation (σ) derived from pilot norm data. The Z-score is then mapped to an IQ scale where Mean = 100 and SD = 15, as defined in modern psychometric standards.
method.p3: A 95% confidence interval (CI) is shown to reflect measurement precision — typically ±6 IQ points based on test–retest reliability and the number of subtests.

theory.heading: Psychometric theory and references
theory.p1: The scoring is aligned with classical test theory (CTT) and item response theory (IRT) concepts used in the development of validated IQ instruments. Items were inspired by public-domain tasks from the International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR; Condon & Revelle, 2014) and related reasoning paradigms in the Cattell–Horn–Carroll model.
theory.p2: The interpretation follows normal-distribution conventions used in major intelligence scales such as the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS-IV), Stanford–Binet, and Raven’s Advanced Progressive Matrices.
theory.p3: Sources: Condon, D. M., & Revelle, W. (2014). The International Cognitive Ability Resource: Development and initial validation of an open-source, public-domain measure. *Intelligence, 43*, 52–64. doi:10.1016/j.intell.2014.01.004. — Wechsler, D. (2008). *WAIS–IV Technical and Interpretive Manual.*

audience.heading: For educators, students, and employers
audience.p1: The structure is intentionally balanced: abstract reasoning, applied numeracy, language comprehension, visual–spatial reasoning, and working memory. This allows use in classrooms (ages 14+), career training, or pre-employment aptitude screening.
audience.p2: Teachers can discuss strengths and learning profiles using the category results. Employers and trainees may interpret it as an indicator of general problem-solving efficiency rather than fixed intelligence.

limitations.heading: Interpretation and limitations
limitations.p1: Scores are approximate and depend on test conditions, motivation, and familiarity with similar puzzles. Repeated use may slightly raise performance due to learning effects.
limitations.p2: This assessment is anonymous, educational, and non-diagnostic. It does not replace standardized testing administered under controlled conditions by qualified psychologists.

iq_explainer.summary: In short: the test uses research-based, standardized methods (mean 100, SD 15) to approximate general cognitive ability. It is suitable for education, research, and self-understanding — presented with transparency and respect for scientific validity.
